byline.contributor: Kristin Hussey reported from Stafford Springs, and Lisa W. Foderaro from New York.
byline.original: By KRISTIN HUSSEY and LISA W. FODERARO

abstract: Concrete foundations of hundreds of homes in northeastern Connecticut built since 1980s are cracking; situation sets up gradual disaster for homeowners, whose homes could potentially lose all value; investigators have traced issue to quarry business Becker Construction Co and related concrete maker, Joseph J Mottes Company, which have ceased selling their products for residential use.
lead_paragraph: The problem, which may affect thousands of homes, poses a thicket of legal, emotional and financial issues for homeowners, who say early warnings were ignored.

headline.main: With Connecticut Foundations Crumbling, ‘Your Home Is Now Worthless’
headline.print_headline: Connecticut Homes Become ‘Worthless’ as Foundations Crack
